The Chapter of Yudhañjaya
The Perfection of Truthfulness
The Story of King Maccha
“Then again, when I was
the king of fish in the great lake,
In the heat of the sun’s rays,
the water in the lake dried up.
Then crows and vultures,
herons and hawks,
Ate me by day and by night,
sitting right next to the fish.
Thinking like this there,
oppressed with my relatives,
‘By what means
can I free my relatives from suffering?’
Having thought about the meaning of the Dhamma,🔽I saw the truth in my vision.
Standing firm in truth, I freed
my relatives from that danger.
Remembering the hundredfold Dhamma,
thinking about the ultimate meaning,
I performed a deed of truth,
which is permanent and stable in the world.
‘Since I remember myself,
since I have attained human understanding,
I do not recall intentionally
harming even a single living being.
By this declaration of truth🔽may Pajjuna rain down!
Pajjuna, rain down!
Destroy the treasure of the crow!
The crow for sorrow, the fish for grief,
I set you free.”
As soon as the excellent truth was spoken,
thunder rumbled;
filling the high and low places,
the rain fell in an instant.
Having spoken this excellent truth,
with supreme effort,
I caused the great rain cloud to rain,
supported by the power of the truth’s majesty;
There is none equal to me in truth—
